author: sinaigimenez
content:
Today I got a reminder of how important love and care are in what we do. Just wanna give a shoutout to @Nomograph Mastering for all the wisdom shared here on that topic.

Long story short — I agreed to mix a track for an American rapper who had already been turned down by some A-list mixers, even though the guy had a decent budget. The reason was kinda obvious: he’s got a personality that leans toward OCD, with everything that comes with that — defensive tone in convos, super long mix notes, and weird stuff like thinking a file sounds different just because it was renamed. (I forgot to label one file as “ref. limited” like the previous versions, and even though it was literally the exact same file, he swore the “non-limited” one had a different top end.)

Stuff like that made me seriously consider walking away from the project like the others did — I could just feel the back-and-forth drama coming. But after my first instinct, I remembered a lot of what’s been talked about here: love, care, and being open to the music and the art. So I decided to try empathy instead of just being a jerk out of frustration.

And honestly? It worked. After taking a bit of time to really talk to him and show I genuinely wanted to help — not just as a mixer, but as a human — I learned he’s totally burnt out and running on fumes 'cause he just became a dad. And I totally get that, since my first kid was born a month ago too. That connection shifted the whole vibe. The next round of notes actually made sense, and we ended up approving the first mix by version 4 — which isn’t bad at all. Happy client, job done.

Not saying you should hang onto toxic clients, but it was a solid reminder: don’t always go with your first reaction. Sometimes just showing a little care  about the person on the other side can change everything. It did for me this time. And tbh, I don’t think I would’ve handled it this way if I hadn’t read some of the stuff shared here. So thanks, y’all. This place is gold.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Re; Brauer workshop

-First 2 days were nothing technical, the 1st conversation he brought up was about TM and how meditation in general has helped him.
-Everything is feel-based, most technical Q's for the first 2 and a half days got the same reply: "It doesn't matter to me, i don't care what the thing is long as it feels good". 
-MHB actually seems to leave the planet while he's mixing, it's wild how immediate he gets into that space. Seemed to go way past "i love mixing and here's all the reasons i'm the shit" and it was inspiring to see the ego leave the equation. His decades of experience are playing directly into his ability to access the story of the song and present it in a compelling, live-feeling way. He mixes from inside the song and performs. Well, he does discovery, then shapes the sounds, then performs just about everything on faders.
-The biggest wake up call to me is that a lot of moves i've made on mixes did not have a good reason behind them. So continuing to ask "why" as I work is gonna be important, because I have to start catching myself and adjusting when the answer to "why" is "because someone said this preset is cool" or "because this is what I do to a vocal/guitar/drums". I feel music very deeply, it's why i got into this, but I feel like i've been poisoned against trusting that instinct and convinced that what we do is a technical job. I'm done being an observer of the art, i want to be bold.
-It's critical to build trust with clients right away, you can't assume anything in what they understand about how you feel. Telling them you love the song and you're excited to mix it is important, and never blaming production/artist/anything else for the mix being less than what it should be. never okay to say "i did my best", because that gives you an out and implies somebody else could do it better
-Therefore, you must believe when you sit down to mix that nobody is gonna interpret this song better than you.
-Generally i'm skeptical to just take on someone else's "method" and start operating in that space just becuase of the success they've had with it. Putting this week into practice is going to mean using his template to get reps in, listening and feeling and interacting in a new way and letting my brain "level up", if you will, then zooming out and making it my own.


I can distill this more and want to share about a couple other specifics, but I just realized I grabbed someone else's notebook by mistake when I left on the last day so I'll need to have them mail mine back to me.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Hey folks, back from mix with the masters with Jon & Teezio. I wanted to share just a little bit in case anyone else here is considering attending a workshop in the future. I was initially on the fence, but am very glad I went. 

Jon & Teezio were amazing together. I don't know how often MWTM does workshops with two engineers, but it really enriched the experience for me. It was actually comical how different their perspectives were on mixing, the business side, motivation for the work, lifestyle, etc... This created fascinating debate / conversation in the group. The Grammy nominations were announced while we were all together and we got to celebrate Jon & Teezio as a group for their I think combined 6 or 7 nominations. They brought in a bucket of champaign. All this after having gone through the sessions for said grammy nominated work earlier in the week. 10 / 10.

Rue Boyer studios is actually insane. Probably the best room I've been in.

There were attendees from all over the world. We ended up sharing mixes and receiving feedback from J&T. Hearing and sharing records in the same room with the people who made them with context provided from varying countries, cultures, genres, and scenes was as enlightening a music listening experience as I'm likely to have for the rest of my life.

So if anyone else here is on the fence in the future. Here's a tiny nudge.

author: bobby k
content: sort of related, but i've been reflecting a lot on how precious it is to maintain a listener's perspective on a work in progress, and what things we can be doing as the producer/mixer/etc to grant that privilege to the artist first and foremost. the simple stuff includes saving the nitty gritty work for your own time, delivering the best mix of the record no matter the stage it's in, focusing any time spent together on how you can make their voice and contributions and ideas the best they can be. some artists love mixing and editing and getting into the weeds, but i'm realizing quite often how much of a duty it is to be the artist, and how record making is only a single slice of that pie. For us it is more or less the whole pie. and a big responsibility we carry (perhaps without realizing?) is that it is our job to protect the artist from getting  stressed out by the process. and this extends to processing and managing our own stress about the work should it exist, as stress is a contagious energy.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Growing up in Ireland, without PP I wouldn’t have known that making records could be a legitimate career.

It showcased real life *professionals* working at a high level, and was my introduction to the discourse around the industry. Having only experienced studio work as a cottage industry up to that point, PP opened my eyes to avenues I could pursue that I wouldn’t have known even existed otherwise (recording engineer is different to mixing engineer is different to producer is different to songwriter??!). It all seems very rudimentary now, but I was starting from literally nothing in a place with few (if any?) visible role models.

I learned so much from it on a technical level - from basic stuff like what a Pultec is and how people use it (connecting the dots between my cracked Waves bundle - Puigtec and who tf JJP was), what “a vocal chain” might look like and the purpose of each stage…

True, the interviews did become unbearable, but there was a golden era between eps around 30-90 at a time when outside of working in the studio world, there weren’t many other sources of good information from people who were really doing it.

Huge appreciation for Dave, and I hope he and his family get the support they need.

author: bobby k
content: In the midst of a kinda unique side quest at the moment - label pulls me in at an hourly rate with an artist (and good friend) that I’ve mixed for many times because the production sessions were such a mess that they felt like they couldn’t even finish the records until some light mixing and organization took place. Songs spread out between multiple project files, DAWs, laptops…vocals tracked to mp3s with the ~50ms delay thing…Some of these producers templates…brilliant stuff. Saw one vocal travel through maybe 7 or 8 auxes and hit probably 4 different rvox’s along the way. It was like a labyrinth of signal flow that was nearly impossible to follow (and once I deleted half the auxes and waves plugins, it started to come back to life). In short they’re having me un-mix it, hand it back for some more production, then do the final mixes later this year. A true testament to the importance of organization and more importantly minimalist, straight forward session files. I wonder how often this need comes up and how feasible it is to be involved ahead of the handoff as a mixer these days. And before you frown at me for griping, this is an absolutely incredible project, many insanely talented musicians I respect. Very right brained, free flowing group. So it felt cool to be able to play more of a part on the project as the more left brained participant and see the stress relief happen in real time.

author: cian riordan
content:
Rich Costey doing a Q&A on the gearspace forum right now and it's just amazing. On mixing the Rage Renegades album with Rick Rubin: 

"Rick called me up after I worked on Fiona Apple "When The Pawn..". I learned a lot from him, primarily how to work from instinct instead of intellect. He would often make mix suggestions which I thought were bad ideas but I would of course do them because it's what he wanted, and they worked. He really did listen like a teenager, it was always simply whether or not he was getting off on something. If he wasn't, he'd make very clear suggestions on how to make something better. Sometimes he'd just say the mix sucked and to start over (only once). Sometimes the recording itself had issues and he would just deal with what's there. I think that turned into a serious strength of his- working with what's in front of him. We still keep in touch from time to time"

author: cian riordan

For whatever reason, the lane I’ve ended up in (and the skill set I’ve honed) is taking less than ideal recordings and productions, and making them sound professional. author: Barbara
content:
Feeling like shite, scheduled an in person mix review, in order to finish this project - communication wasn't being effective, so I though it would be easier this way to get something that would make us both proud.
Got the dry files from the producer 1h before meeting with the band.

The project is finished on my side. On to mastering now. Today feels like the first day of my life 😆

All of this to say what I think is really important and some things I learned that I wish I knew when I was in the middle of those project blues:
1) you WILL get through it.
2) it might be possible to turn it down or pass it to another person
3) trust yourself and your skills to make the best you can
4) set boundaries and expectations. From the start. With the artist and yourself.
5) try to find something you can enjoy during the process - to me, it was on the very last day of mixing that I changed something on my workflow that got me excited, helped me get to the sound of the album we were looking for and will probably be something I will do for every project from now on
6) surround yourself from colleagues/friends who can help you - I know this needs a strike of luck too, but I'm sure if you don't have a reliable in-person "work friend" who can be there for you (with kindness, while keeping it real), this discord might be a good place to ask for that kind of help.

author: cian riordan
content: For mix work, I rarely do work-in-progress checks anymore. Although, I'll usually try and listening to mastering returns in Airpods or the car first to get a feel for how it sounds in the real world before geeking out in the studio. When I'm producing & mixing something, I'm often working on it over a longer stretch of time and find real value in listening to something in Airpods while on an airplane or driving around. Given how tuned in we can be as record-makers, I'm always amazed at how valuable passive listening is. I'm usually finding broad stroke adjustments that I can make down the road that really serve the project well.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: A huge part of the gig is loving what you are given, really loving it. Not wishing it was something different, or "remixing" via processing, or lecturing clients about levels etc. All the best I've seen have that love and respect for what they are given.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Awesome. I'm seeing this right now with a friend's band, so ima jump on the bandwagon here. I just took over mixing the album, which has been in progress for years. Everybody tells me the producer/band leader is this prolific asshole, constantly blowing up at people and impossible to please. The previous mixer had been mixing this thing for months/over a year and everyone was worn out/not getting results. I was really reluctant to take on the project for fear of being intimidated/failing to deliver.

I've made a point of greeting the producer at every step with clear communication, enthusiasm, and an open mind. I genuinely love the music and have made a point of letting him know how much fun it's been to work on the stuff. And, similar to your story, we were basically approved on the first track within 4 mixes and the guy seemed really really happy.

Everyone just said this guy was a hopeless asshole, but what I saw was a guy who was working so hard to bring a vision to life and just struggling to get there; self-financing, overseeing everything, etc... and it's fairly complex, hip hop and soul vibes with practically a full orchestra and 3 vocalists, so it's a lot to manage. Not trying to excuse the asshole behavior, but I see the frustration and I really wanted to highlight how much cool work he had done and that, without any fuss or needless back and forth, we would just get it where it needed to go. i tried to just think about how exciting it could be to finally hear these songs that've been bouncing around in his head actually come out of the speaker the way he imagined. We've got 7 songs almost done now and I've grown so much just from these attitude alignments i've picked up from spending time here.

author: Rollmottle
content: Many songs come out of the mixing stage sounding "done." Those songs could still benefit from perspective. I would not describe that as "a lot of the mastering processes happening in the mixing stage." For me, mastering is the process by which I 100% align the final product with the artistic intent. There's a technical component to that, but there's also a huge component of that that is pure vibe. Can I enhance the feeling of this song without getting in the way? Is the feeling of this song fully realized? Is the feeling of these songs together fully realized? Uncovering all that to me is the job. Sometimes it's already there and there's very little, if anything, to do. The perspective is still valuable. The key here is somebody who both understands the technical aspects of the job as well as somebody who can internalize and FEEL the music. The latter is why I believe mastering is one of the most misunderstood processes.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I'm totally with you on all this.

The question for me is less about the credit/ title, and more about the role. How do you get perspective at the end of the record making process? This role is changing, and we'd all be smart to understand where it's headed.

I get hired to finish songs a lot. Usually that means I have a "co-producer" credit. Sometimes it means "mixer" credit. Occasionally it's included "mastering." But really what I'm hired for is that combination of experience and technical knowledge. I'm an outside ear who knows how to fix what's missing. This role of "finisher" is really where a lot of the producer/ mixer/ mastering engineer profession is headed. The distinction between those roles is getting blurrier. 

Mixing engineers have moved from pulling up faders on the console and creating a mix (old school "mixers") to often just pulling up the rough mix of stems and making finishing touches (Jon, Manny, Serban, Tony, Bainz, etc.).

In this way, the "mixing engineer" profession is moving away from manipulating raw sounds to manipulating nearly finished mixes. This is sounding more and more like what a "mastering engineer" does. Now there's "stem mixing" and "stem mastering" too, further blurring the lines. These are all just slightly different configurations of the same thing. Who do you hire to get perspective and then act on it?

Those of us that are finishers or mixers or mastering engineers or whatever would be smart to think about how to adapt to the direction this is all headed. 

I want us all to win. I think we need to step back and expand how we think about the roles. It's the best way for us all to have careers.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is such an unpopular take, but the people that I know that are truly great are making a living at it. Maybe not as much as they “should” (sometimes if I want to hate my life I imagine what my house would look like if the success I had was in the 80s and 90s and not the last 15 years) but again, it really does come to doing actually great work. “Work harder, suck less”. Ruqaurphï’s advice is really the best advice: focus, and bust ass. There’s a limited amount of slots out here of people that get to make a living out of what most do as a hobby; someone out there is willing to out hustle you and will lap you no matter how much of a head start being gifted gave you.

The other day I had brought up in the monitoring thread about how the quality of work has been diluted by how easy it is now to do adequate work. The “my cousin has a 5D, he can shoot your wedding for $50!” problem. Yet Glenn Luchford still gets 6 figures for photo shoots. Quality wins.

Yesterday I got to hang with Zack Cervini’s gf at a baby shower. Zack just bought a house. Cause he’s been kicking everyone’s ass at a certain genre of mixing and took his “internship to asst to fuck you pay me” mixer path seriously. There is still money to be made.

author: cian riordan
content: First time I pulled an all nighter with EV was when he was mixing a Slash live album (Made in Stoke). We had to mix in 5.1 so we had NS10s setup around the console on old tape boxes and had everything up on the console. It was just under 2 hrs of music and we each took an end of the console and were just going at it with Flying Faders... I think thats where I really learned about the power of automation. How much more effective it is just to turn something up or down for a second as opposed to trying to compress/EQ/or saturate your way out of a problem.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I’m with Beckley on this. I get hired because of my taste, and I go into projects with full communication re: what is intended. 

I don’t say “this sucks I’m gonna fix it.” I say “I have some ideas about how to pull this into a really kickass place.” 

Very rarely as a mixer am I *only* mixing. Bass comes in and has no booty? Chances are I’m gonna be doing more than bx-subsynth to make it thump. Only tracked one guitar and it’s supposed to be huge? I’m gonna add some to really make that sell. 

I don’t always assume I know more than the artist, but the truth is, with the level of artists I usually work with, MOST of the time I do. 

That’s not an ego trip, it’s an understanding of the gig. It’s why people hire me. Why they ask for my help. And I treat that with deep respect. 

Last night Rauirí basically bullied me into buying RX standard for a project I was doing as a favor to a friend. I SPENT MONEY to do this thing. Because as Rauirí says: “Art matters.” 

And as Beckley ranted yesterday, I don’t think we should let something suck because we were only hired for a job. We’re not house painters who decided to fix a furnace. We’re general contractors who know how a house is built, and we fix shit that’s broken. (Bad example, but you get it.)

author: Oli J
content:
My standard mix deliverables are…

- Main, instrumental, acapella, TV (lead vocal muted)
- Cleans of above where applicable
- Grouped stems (drums, bass, vocals etc) including cleans - vocals wet and dry
- Separate stems (every track solo and bounced through mix bus) including clean versions 
- Committed pro tools mix session (final mix session with all plugins committed) + cleans

author: joshbonanno
content: i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face....wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great, because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist...or in some cases, even the intended audience. with that said...if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. / might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it...so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world...but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Also think about turnaround times. You work on 15+ songs a day as an ME, you hear aberrant clicks and pops in *nearly every single one of them* 

With asking the person who sent you the files to do it, you spend your whole day emailing and managing files. It takes longer to open gmail than it does to zap the click. 

And think of the logical conclusion of asking the mixing engineer to fix the edit. They don’t have the edit, they have the comp. So then if you extend the logic they have to hit up the producer, and MAYBE the producer has to hit up the recording engineer if you really wanna “get to the source”. It’s like the meme of the producer who didn’t want to use splice because it was cheating and ended up farming sheep to get skin to make his own drumheads. Just do the fucking work. There’s no time to email back and forth about things that can be fixed immediately

author: Brian Reynolds
content: So I climbed into my 2010 Volvo S80 today. And for the first time in 2025. I was going to listen to my music on the speakers. I plugged in my usb c adapter. Into the coaxial cable that runs into the center console, for that true old analog gold plated warmth. Turned the windows and volume all the way up, then as I prepared to hit play. I was blanketed with the all to familar tension. That very same feeling from when I was going to have to sit next to one of the two dudes on the middle school basketball team. Who took as their daily task, to pay homage to ancestral animal social structures, by drowning any nearby male counter part with sack taps, donkey punches, and nail whip flicks. You just preemptively flinch at the inevitable pain from their onslaught. I hit play on a mix that is -5.8 lufs at peak. No proverbial donkey punch to my thighs this time. The song didn't overload the speakers at any point. As I heard the mix in my studio. I heard it here. The things I loved about it. I loved it here. The things I was unsure about. I was equally unsure about them here. My eyes welled up a bit with fulfillment and gratitude. It took me longer and cost more than I could of ever imagined, when I started this journey. But I got here. No longer do I have to worry about translation of the mix. I can focus all my worry on the feeling and vibe of the performace. I'm willing to let my ego have this one, this mix punches with any modern mix on earth. On any system. (Sounds killer on the Meta Ray Bans. And those speakers are rutheless honest. Ive heard alot of overloaded low end mixes on em) And back to the gratitude. I wanted to thank this place. I couldn't have done it without yall. I'd still be in a pitch black room looking for a switch that felt like it was hidden on the ceiling. Now back to work! Have a great day yall!!

author: spectrummasters
content:
This completely resonates with me. The business of music doesn’t sit as well with me as the business of construction. There’s a camaraderie and kinship in physical labour on construction projects, and an embodied intelligence in that world that offsets the subjective and (for me) atomised work of hours alone mixing.

When I’m doing construction work, I’m also free to think objectively and from a distance about my audio engineering work.

Most of all, something changes for me when I’m being paid for musical “work” that I’m not entirely happy with. I’ve discussed this privately with a few folks here, and it seems the relationship between music and its commodification is problematic for more than a few of us. Simply put, it’s sometimes less enjoyable — though equally amazing — being paid for a passion.

I couldn’t recommend a construction or skilled trade career enough. It’s incredibly flexible and offers a tonic to music careers: you know you can walk onto a site tomorrow and get paid quickly and well. It’s always going to be around, and in my case, the certifications allow me to consider migrating to most economies globally as a skilled worker.

Construction allows me to be my own patron for my musical endeavours, and that feels really good.

I’d love to see a bigger debate here about how working in the upper echelons of the music industry feels long term — challenges, payoffs, economics, job security, retirement, healthcare, family life versus work life, and a world where socialising is networking.

Construction is a simpler engagement: competency, find a solution, do the work, go home.

I came across @cian riordan discussing becoming a fireman on Conversations, and much of what you said, Cian, is exactly what I get from construction.

I love how for you, though — instead of the firehouse bell calling, it was multiple Grammys!

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
I moved here 2 years ago with a bunch of savings and making very little money in music. It took me about a year to pull in enough income from mixing and spotify streams where I could stop living off savings and only on music income. 

But, It IS so expensive to live here, and I like to do things. typical night out is like $80 after drinks and ubers. Gas is $80. An egg sandwich is $16 lol. The constant worrying of if i was going to make enough that month got to me, so of a couple months ago, I returned to a freelance software engineering gig 3 days a week. Never been happier. A _lot_ of people in LA are doing the same: _side hustles are your friend_ . 

Another thing i'd add is when you first move here, try to combine your studio and living expenses. Studio spots here start at like $1800 a month and go up from there. I live in a beautiful house in silverlake with roommates where I have a room, my own bathroom, _and my own studio_ in the furnished garage for $1300. Try to get something like that.

author: Rollmottle
content: haha...I'm a UX designer by trade and would have approached this problem differently. i don't know that we actually have a problem where we need a more structured and rigid way of soliciting feedback on music. maybe in certain high volume scenarios, i can see the use case. for mixing and mastering, putting an interface in front of somebody that makes a user think "oh shit, i can comment down to the every last second!" seems ripe for 1. woodshedding and focusing on things that in any other listening context wouldn't matter 2. makes me think I *have* to say something. as my client, i'd much rather you take the music wherever you feel most comfortable in whatever way you want to consume and just listen and then communicate back to me however you'd like without the pressure of a UI that might be unnatural to that workflow in front of you. it's a philosophical thing i suppose...i never want to add friction to your natural way of thinking about something, especially your own music.

author: Barbara
content:
I have to let you know my first experience with this. Been working on an album that I recorded one year ago. Recording took us 7 days and they still needed to add synths and bass fot some of the songs after that (side note: the production wasn't finished by the time we tracked, so I edited everything I had - 10 songs, none of them with less than 5 minutes. It was the band's first time in the studio, also, and had to edit lots of drums and bass stuff). After doing a first pass, I sent them the multitracks they asked for, to track the rest of their stuff with their producer (a colleague of mine). The next 8 months were spent waiting on their files to start mixing (this was supposed to last 1/2 months, max). When I finally got the files, you have no ideia how messy the project turned out (track names, bounce mistakes, ultrapocessed tracks with artifacts - even the ones we've tracked at the studio before, audible edit points,... all you can imagine going wrong at this point), so it took me a bunch of time to organize everything in a way that I could work with what I've got (going back and forth asking the producer for some files that didn't even get to me or asking if there was the possibility to get some of the tracks dry, without processing or fx - keep this in mind).

Needless to say, when I was ready to start mixing, I was already overwhelmed and tired of it, and I knew I still had a long way to go...

First version took me probably too long to get right (2 months, approx., working on other projects that got scheduled on those 8 months) and I've sent it before I went on a few days vacation.

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
Schedule, schedule, schedule. I use a productivity app called Notion. Make multiple bottles ahead of time. That way you don’t have to stop working to make a bottle. You can pull them out of the refrigerator whenever you need, warm em up and you’re good to go. Most formula last at least 24 hours in the refrigerator. Breast milk is easier to work with because you can freeze it, grab it, and thaw it when you’re ready to use it. Plan your breaks around feeding. When he’s playing or napping, you can work. Make sure he’s visible tho. Have a bassinet, bouncer, or something next to your chair. Open backs help when mixing because you can hear if he cries. Babies love white noise. Play that shit on loop while he sleeps and he’ll be out for hours at a time. Use brown switches for your keyboard if you can get them. Those are extremely quiet and won’t wake the baby. 

That’s off of the top of my head. I might think of something else and add it here. CONGRATULATIONS!!!

author: cian riordan
content: Nail on the head. I think I had mentioned this in a previous post, but these days notes tend to come in real time -- via text messages, dropbox comments, or sometimes even thoughtful emails. I'll usually take a quick glance, but then dump everything into a note file so I have everything in one place when I sit to do the revision. This can be useful when you'll get a thread of notes like 1) I'm not sure about the drum sound, it feel so x... then 2) someone else will chime in saying I love the drums! I think x is the problem then 3) first person is hesitant and shrugs of their not, even though it may still bother them. That way I can try and string together some sort of move that will hopefully make everyone happy. If you're dealing with a band -- and you're producing/engineering -- you'll have had the benefit of seeing the dynamic. Sometimes you get some people that are more engaged and tweaky, others that are unsure of EVERYTHING, and then people that when they say something, they're usually right, as infrequent as that may be. This is very useful during mix notes time because you have context. If you're just getting flies flown to you and you've never met the band/artist, thats certainly a bit more of a challenge and will likely require more work on your end to smooth things out.

author: peterlabberton
content: Thinking about numbers, i.e. a 2 db boost vs 4 db, and then endlessly ABing/being conservative with moves to a fault. At my old staff engineer gig I got to assist Joe Chiccarelli on a handful of tracking/mixing sessions. The most eye opening was assisting him mixing the latest Hellogoodbye record. He’d mix 2 songs a day on average, and just breeze through cranking on the 550 eqs in the console—not a care in the world what the numbers said. I’d take recall notes and print stems/various mixes and he and the band would go have lunch/dinner. Seeing him repeatedly just crank on shit until it sounded compelling was huge. Obviously, you need to have developed the instincts to do that tastefully and have it sound great, but that sent me down a path of being fearless and trying to not get hung up on looking at shit.

author: Rollmottle
content: I'd pick one path and roll with it. As somebody's who's been at this crossroads (mixing & mastering vs. one or the other), I realized that to do one or the other the way I wanted to and do it right, I'd have to commit to one. And each of those paths imply different studio set ups and ergonomics and mindsets. I had 2 paths, you have 3. That’s a lot to ask of 1 space IMO. I don’t know how I could pull all of those disciplines off in the same space without feeling like I’m making a compromise somewhere. Tracking and mixing seem most compatible from a "one space" perspective. I bet focusing on tracking and mixing will be a relief and pay dividends for you. Your knowledge having done mastering before will be an asset to you in the tracking and mixing phase and make your end product even better.

author: Slow Hand
content:
There was a bit of talk in #👩🍳mixing-talk where folks were describing how speaking on podcasts refined their ability to speak.

To keep the audio/speaking analogies rolling, I constantly remind myself that word choice and vocabulary are akin to dynamic range in speech.

Referring to everything as "fire" at one end of the emotional range, and "shit" on the other end is akin to making a hyper-compressed track that's sausaged at 6 LUFS. It's exciting initially, but diminishes in effectiveness over time if there is no contrast from moment to moment.

If you can use finer and finer gradations of meaning to make your point, then your words have more heft and more expression with which to make them.

author: Rollmottle
content: I've been a software designer for almost 25 years and still do it. Been running a label, making/releasing music and doing mixing and mastering for that whole time as well. About 3 years ago it clicked that mastering is my thing and decided to spend the last few years dialing in my rig and room around mastering. I have designs on having this be my full time gig at some point, but I'm taking it slow, honing my craft and building my client base and studio while the steady paycheck is there. author: cian riordan
content: When I'm having the intro conversation before I start mixing, I usually tell the client that my V1 is almost always my favorite. I've mixed the song this way because its how I hear things, and most changes tend to deviate away from that -- and thats OK! But just know thats where I'm coming from on most heavy-handed revisions. When I send back the revision, i will put my notes in bold/color next to their notes... usually explaining what I did in vague detail. If it was a note like you're referring to above where I don't really agree with it, I'll make the adjustment best I can, say that I don't agree with it, but here it is anyways. If it's something I feel really strongly about -- I'll still execute, but be a little more forceful in my language saying something like 'I really don't think this is a good idea, but hear it anyways'. You want the band to know that you're open to feedback but that you also have skin in the game and care about the end product. This is something that gets easier down the line once you build up a rapport.

author: spectrummasters
content:
im defo going through this chapter at the mo, and i like it. Im having some sort of psychological re-alignment with what i do and why. From sheer stupidity i managed to delete 70, 000 files . I've recovered the files but all the directories and filenames are gone. i was faced with the dilemma ....give up months? of my downtime...renaming and filing these files....or hunt back through my time machine disks and re-create these back-ups....or just move on.

Moving on has proven to be a bit weirdly easy and has left me reflecting on this:

If ive given up days and days of spending time with loved ones to work at the computer (which i have ) in my studio .....inside, and not in nature (which re-charges me) for all these digital dalliances that then vanish into the ether ....and iim cool with that......then was it the right thing to have ever done that at all ? Should i have just been sat with my baby boy for that extra 3 hours that day. 

My response so far (as you know ) has been to go laptop-based and mobile and break the chain to my studio set-up . This weekend im mixing for the first time away from my studio and with family. it feels cool. 

I know why i do music, because i have to......the time i give to mixing and serving the whims of the client ....this is something im examining more closely now. And that feels wise. Life moves fast, i dont want to spend a huge chunk of it in a fashion that isnt who i am.....screen-based and inside

author: BatMeckley
content:
I would say there’s a huge disconnect between information and knowledge these days. Due to the absolute deluge of information, people have become confused at the difference between reading about something, or seeing it on YouTube, and actually having done it, and the experience that brings. I find (at least in my line of work) so many people gorging on gearspace, YouTube videos, even mixing with the masters, and then thinking (and even proclaiming) they’ve translated this information into actual knowledge.

There’s a tremendous amount of upside with all of the avenues of learning we now have, there’s very few things broken in my house that I can’t fix after a YouTube video. But I don’t consider myself a contractor, or a plumber, or an electrician, just because I watched a few videos of some guy telling me how to fix my light switch.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
I got really sad when I saw this. It probably hits harder because my dad is around the same age and has Parkinson’s it's not the same but… 
 Dave always seemed like a genuinely good person, and I’m grateful for how he tried to spread knowledge.

I’m with Cian on the interview quality — a lot of them were just awkward (the Justin Meldal-Johnsen one is a perfect example), and the absolute worst part was Herb. In the end, his stupid ego kinda killed the show. It was really annoying how he kept interrupting all the time and talking way more than Dave or the guest, about random shit that had nothing to do with the conversation. Fucking terrible.

BUT I can’t forget that back in the day, Pensado’s Place was one of the very few places where you could actually see your mixing heroes talk about making records. Even when the interviews were pretty bad like 85% of the time, I still had great moments watching Eric Valentine, Tchad Blake, JMJ, Ken Andrews, etc… and I learned some useful stuff too.

I’m from a small village in Northwest Spain (BTW, I heard Pensado has family roots here), and I had zero access to any info about how real records were made. So when I discovered Pensado’s Place, it was huge for me. Big thanks to Dave!! And I wish him nothing but the best in this sad new chapter. Good people and love for this art will always win for me, no matter the flaws. ❤️

author: peterlabberton
content:
In my experience, if I’m mixing and not also producing, there’s almost always (maybe just always always?) someone who can act as a tie breaker. The producer, lead singer/songwriter, guitar dude who is clearly leading the charge creatively, a manager, etc. etc. who you can turn to in order to give definitive direction... maybe during covid this is more difficult as I feel that often can become clear organically in the room.

If it’s truly a situation where there are contradictory/unproductive notes coming in, maybe either a) tell them they need to decide amongst themselves and then give you a clear list of notes, or b) take the lead yourself and really push for what you feel serves the song best/explain why the sax can’t be 10x louder than the lead vocal? Which option is best I’d say depends on your relationship with them, how much of a lead you want to take creatively, how confident you are in making the right choices for this song, etc. etc.

At least that’s what I’d do. 🤷🏻‍♂️ @cian riordan might have better advise for these situations!

author: peterlabberton
content: Took this 100% from @cian riordan, but: separate output path for references! I send the mix out 1-2, references out 3-4, and any old mix passes/rough mixes out 5-6. They are all level matched and I can switch between them on my monitor controller. The level matching and real time switching right in front of me is key, to me. I resisted this for ages out of some misplaced sense of pride, but, dude, if you don’t have a good system for references... do it! I also have the outputs of my computer audio routed to record into the ref track via a pair of virtual channels in UAD Console, so I can pull something up on Tidal (!) and record it in directly.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I’ve got a similar but different hack for A/B’ing between a reference on my Ableton template without the need for multiple outputs:

I drag my reference track or rough mix onto a muted *Reference* channel and set up a hotkey that does two things when I press it:

1) It solo’s the reference track and...

2) It bypasses all of the master buss processing on my master buss. So that the *Reference* isn’t being processed when I solo it.

Boom. Instant A/B referencing in Ableton.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Any band that wouldnt want Andy Wallace is a band I probably wouldn’t want to work with. They clearly confuse frequency response with quality, like someone that thinks a harsh bright mic sounds “better”.

Andy Wallace is brilliant and his records sound incredible, more importantly FEEL incredible, because he’s constantly mixing the song, constantly making decisions. Like a shit hot live band playing off each other Andy’s faders are always moving, parts are constantly responding to other parts, decisions are being made about sonic and part priorities.

I think one of the main reasons when i asked the round table what their favorite mixes were, almost no modern mixes (last 5-10 years or so) came up.

It’s a hard concept for me to verbalize, but I think we have a lot of people focused on the wrong thing and misunderstanding WHY mixes resonated, and now they’re all chasing the wrong thing. Like my thoughts on if you asked a berklee student who the best guitarist was they’d pick some shredder, because they think technical wizardry is the benchmark, when the people whose playing makes you FEEL something tend to go way farther.

Enough mixers think that a clean 26hz and a saturated 26k is what the goal of a mix is and you end up with a bunch of songs that are really clear but really boring and uninspiring.

author: Deleted User
content:
@joshbonanno said:

i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face... 

wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great. 

because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist. In some cases, even the intended audience. with that said, if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. 

/ might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it. 

so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. 

this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world. but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: Rob Domos
content:
I just got a haircut that made think about communication with things like mix notes. 

I walked in with shoulder length hair and wanted a maintenance trim of about two inches off.  

Now it just so happens that my stylist had a mullet going down to exactly the length I wanted, so when describing it to him, I said “basically your length, but not a mullet, like not short on the sides”

Homeboy proceeded to cut my hair down to a 1940s business man short but with poofy sides. He thought I meant the length of his front, because I had said “your length but not a mullet”. 

I thought I’d been very clear and still got the complete opposite of what I wanted. 

My question is: Do we know if/when we are doing this with mix notes? 

Ie. Someone says they want something “clearer”, so we boost top end - but really the issue they were having was the hashy aliasing masking the diction and our boost just made it worse. 

When engaging with artist requests, are we knee jerk reacting to the literal words in the notes email, or are we truly grasping *why* the artist is asking for something? Do we feel what is underneath their request?

content: I think it has to do with the weird power thing like there’s a sense of a god feeling when you’re mixing on a huge PA with that much power and for whatever reason a lot of peoples taste goes right out the window. “ look what I can do.” The other thing I’ve noticed is when I voice the PA at a new venue I walk into the subs  are usually 6 to 10 DB too loud and most major PAs go down to at least 50 Hz the subs for me or added in lightly. author: Eric Martin
content:
I think always consider who has the final say? Is it you? If it’s you make yourself happy, if it’s the band, get as close to making yourself happy as you can and make the band so excited that they’ll never forget how you helped them.

I find that when I’m mixing the first mix is what I want it to be, then the band fucks it up trying to get what they want, bass player wants the bass to be important, guitar player the guitars etc, if they’re all happy then you, should be happy, if you’re not, then that’s the ego, right?

author: Zack Hames
content: This may be weird advice, but sometimes I just say “sure!” (Or completely disregard depending on context) To certain ideas or mix notes and choose not to address them again. It doesn’t always work but sometimes people just say stuff to say stuff, and they may listen to the mix several times again and get used to how it is and not even want the change later or remember they said anything. I know that may sound insulting but I just dealt with this exact thing, and that did save me a few times. If they brought it up again I tried to meet in the middle. I started experimenting with this once I realized being super honest/straight forward/transparent can actually slow down the process without any benefit. This may apply to more commercial productions where people don’t really want a “no” or a “why not” they just want a yes man and a person to get the job done. I hope that makes sense, I feel like some of the other options you’ve definitely already came up with. Sometimes making your case with the utmost confidence can also work! (Not something I do often but it absolutely can work)

author: peterlabberton
content: Personally, I don't really bother taking these kinds of notes while tracking. If I'm producing something myself, I prefer to just keep moving and try something, then move on as quickly as possible. If it needs to be redone for some reason, I'll just cook up a sound again and not get too hung up on whether it's identical or not—chances are if we're revisiting it, things could be improved anyway. If I'm engineering for someone else, I'll defer to them, but these are usually situations where things are even *more* time-sensitive (i.e. we're renting an expensive studio), and the situation is very unlikely to be recreated anyway. I was very lucky to have subbed in for @cian riordan with St. Vincent for a couple months in the early stages of this new record—nothing was documented (unless I grabbed a quick photo to cover my own ass), it was all just trying stuff, and if it worked it worked, if not, move on and forget it! Mixing is another story—in the (increasingly) rare instance when I'm mixing on a console, I'll figure out some way of recalling for that particular project. This is usually more or less @Rollmottle's method, except I go even more jank-ass and just scribble song names on a post-it and hold it in front of a piece of gear like a mugshot. Anything on the console is either stored in the console automation, or, like the most recent project I mixed on a console, I'll just calibrate all the faders and run stuff through it, but really *mix* in Pro Tools still. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@David Fuller it seems like the Jon Castelli "finisher" role is going to encompass mastering at some point soon. everyone is already "mixing" as they produce and write (in the traditional sense of balancing and eq'ing and compressing). then someone like jon takes *the existing mix* and finishes it. the argument of having an experienced ear outside perspective is totally correct. that's what a mixer now is becoming. then from there a mastering engineer does... another even more subtle layer of sonic refinement but only to the 2 track bounce? and then decides how loud it will be? i get that this has some value, but based on the evolution of the technology and the roles of "mixers" these days, it seems like hiring a mastering engineer is going to become a luxury equivalent to hiring a second co-mixer or something. or getting real strings on a record or something. 

why spend the money if you already have one sonic finisher?

author: Zack Hames
cian riordan
content: And it will go down and down the chain. Why hire a mixing engineer when the producer gets it so close? Or why hire a producer when the artists demos are so good that you can just release that? Why have a songwriter when the artists just write their own songs? I don't disagree with you at all. I know that this is the case and am sure that my pirate ship is sailing in shallow waters... it's only a matter of time before I wash ashore. While I do applaud the evolution of the music making process and the ingenuity of the players moving the needle, if I *were* to make a stupid line graph, I don't think the quality of the work will rise as fast as high as the increase in efficiency... it's likely to invert.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i'm not actually quite saying that. i'm saying that most projects will only need one "outside ear" at the end of the process. mixer/ finisher/ mastering engineer will be one role rather than two. 

mastering used to be about technical knowledge for delivering different physical media. it was also nice to have one extra set of ears on a project after the tracking/mixing engineer (who was the same person from the 1930s to 1980s). but now we're going back to the tracking engineer and mixing engineer being the same person (possibly the producer and writer as well). there really only needs to be one more step. mixer/ mastering/ finishing gonna be the same role.

also fully agree that quality will continue to decline as more technically untrained people make music. 

btw i'm not arguing good or bad for any of this. just seems likely that's where we're headed

author: LAPhill
content: I know you're joking, but what is the point of spatial audio? To immerse the listener in a world of music. To create a 3D experience. Why? We can go outside and listen to a band in a room and hear reflections all around us. But there is a chance to go deeper with spatial audio, to create something hyper-real, as much of record making has always been. Every new technology has the opportunity to enhance or detract from our experiences, and we have to meet them where they are. Maybe Atmos ain't it, but as someone who spends a lot of time in surround.. there is a feeling to immersing yourself in sound that isn't going to come from two speakers. So yes.. mixing in Atmos can very much be a part of steering the ship.

author: Barbara
content:
Even though I understand where you come from with this - I guess everyone relates and/or feels more emotionally connected with some projects than others - I think we should own what we do. If you're recording/mixing/producing, do it as best as you can. That can mean passing it on to someone else (and handle this part with care, in my opinion, is also a part of the job). But if you end up going all the way, it still is a worthy project, you should still give it 100% of yourself. Learn something new and useful. And if you do, you should be proud of having your name on something you know you gave your best (even if the rest of it wasn't ideal, your part was the best you could do, at least in a certain moment in time).

So, I'm all for: work in it, own it. But make sure you do your best all the times and always learn something.

I finally got around to watching the Castelli mixes Kaien Cruz JFTR.  That mix is an incredible lesson in so many ways. author: spectrummasters
content:
For me , LWMR sets itself apart because it never really struck me as claiming to be introducing some new ground breaking invention / product / idea …..but much more focused on understanding the origins and evolutions of good working practices and why . 

This resonated with me because , I really find myself thinking…..for all these new products like soothe / gullfoss / cla vocals / TGP ….and now stem splitters ….how much better do the records being made today sound / feel than those in the 70s ( for example ) . Like we came out of mono and into stereo and Jesus gains were made .!..for all the new clever software have we made those sorts of gains from it ? I think loudness techniques yes defo , but otherwise ? Hmmm . I feel like the best records today are being made by people who really know their engineering ish…..like LWMR was kinda all about imho . 

So it feels like a lot of the promo on “analogue emulations / stem splitters / multi band resonance tools “ …..although very clever ….kind of miss the point when it comes to becoming good at this mindfuck of mixing

author: dylannash
content:
What are some of your favourite elements of your prod/mix templates? I currently have a separate production/writing template and then another for mixing but I’m trying to hybridise and streamline them a little more to get faster results and hopefully focus on the song. Also, most of the songs I mix tend to be one’s I’ve written and produced as well, so hoping to cut down on session set-up time.

Some of mine are an instant “duck bus”, which I picked up from Ian Kirkpatrick. It’s a pre-loaded aux with something like LFO Tool or shaper box on it, so you can quickly route and uniformly make things side chain.

Another quick workflow thing I love is having Pro Tools audio playlists with a bunch of reverse sweeps, impacts and other transition fx/ear candy hidden and ready to go in the session, so you can quickly try out a bunch. 

I also have the trim plugin added as the first and last plugin on every new track preset, as I use them to quickly manage the gain in and out of each track and so I don’t have to search for them constantly.

Ozone Spectral shaper on some music busses and as a replacement for Soothe on the mix bus has also been a real win (thanks Jon!) Although these sorta things aren’t turned on whilst writing as they have a ton of latency.

Keen to hear what you all find useful!

author: Eric Martin
content: I route my mix bus to a print bus and can use this as a ref A/B by toggling the input, then if I have a ruff mix or a ref I can choose the playlist of which one then I never process on a master, always mix bus process and print to the print bus, that way I can hear and SEE my mix getting printed in real-time as a check to make sure everything “looks” right as it sounds right

author: Josh
content:
I mean, yes and no. 

It’s not about if it’s just good or bad. 

It’s about if it matches with the audience. 

There are great songs that can’t make it on the radio. There are great songs that can’t be played live because they don’t translate with the audiences energy. They still aren’t bad songs. Their intent is just different. 

I think you’re mistaking the idea of “bad” for “wrong”. 

There aren’t bad songs. There’s just wrong songs. Not every choice made during writing/production/mixing is going to resonate with everyone.

author: ALXCPH
content:
For the guys using Saturn 2 to add some harmonics to a Sound(not really changing the Sound to something different)

do you guys use it at 100% w’et with a lower drive % og do you go lower wet% but higher drive%. 

Fx on vocals
For me at least i Think using the “warm” settings at 100 percent darkens the Sound too much to be usable. So ill usually stick to something like “clean tube” if going 100%wet and like 10% drive or ill go lower on the wet% if im using the “warm tube” but higher drive%.

Sometimes ill use it on my mixbuss very slightly to emulate some nonexistant tube gear on my mixbuss.

I never really use it in multiband mode as i (thanks to matts Big words) use specter for frequency specific harmonic enhancement. 

Would love to hear how you guys use it. 🙂

author: Eric Martin
content:
As long as there’s someone out there that has listened/worked on more music than the person who is the Mixer or Producer and has a “technically better” or more accurate playback system than said producer there will be a viable job for the ME when it comes to releasing music IMO, not everyone will pay to do it, but the people who want to put out the “best work” will, the job will change, it already has many times, but the responsibility will stay.

FWIW at Abbey Road in the 50’s/60’s the new engineers started in the cutting room so that they learned exactly what was possible to put on the records as it was cut, then they gradually worked  their way back from cutting to working in the room with an artist.

I think this process is insanely valuable, I just did my first “true” tracking session in over a year and after mainly Mastering and Mixing for the last year/two my tracking mixes sounded dang finished.

Most mixes I do all in the box and the little outboard I have helps shape the tracking upfront and doesn’t get used in Mastering, but does get used sometimes in mixing.

I operate out of my home studio which provides low overhead, my “studio” is where my band rehearses and where I Mix and Master, I also bring bands in occasionally to track in my basement, but it a little tight.

I wonder what y’all’s thoughts are, I love doing all these things but feel like, I’m just kinda stuck treading water and not swimming toward a destination.

This Andrew Scheps podcast is fantastic. I’m not through this episode yet and I keep meaning to turn it off and get to work but, here I am, still at it. Highly recommended!

I was happy a few weeks ago to pick out a 16k tone ringing in a pretty big indie rock release that apparently never got caught in mixing or mastering. This was reassuring, but I know that I also definitely have a dip in the upper mids in my right ear—my guess is from years of drumming as a lefty, aka hihat on the right. In the last year or two I’ve always had a plug-in to flip left and right as the last step of my monitoring path that I can un-bypass to have a reality check. In addition to making sure there’s not an inappropriately loud guitar on the right, it’s just a great perspective shift.

author: Zack Hames
content: Do you have any way of recording at home? You mention "while you are not actually recording". The best way to practice is to literally do it as often as possible even if it's by yourself. You won't train the social aspect, you won't really train problem solving of an external source (a guitarist with a particularly shitty amp or playing technique per-say), but you can certainly experiment endlessly on capturing sounds. Shootouts, micing techinques, it's pretty much endless. If you don't have a recording setup at home or are in an apartment where you can't be as loud as you'd want, I try to absorb as much information as I can. Podcasts (Andrew Talks to Awesome People / Unstoppable Recording Machine / Working Class Audio / Conversations Audio), Online articles, (Sound on Sound) GearSpace Forum Q+A, TapeOp interviews, Youtube Series (Making Records with EV, Sounds-Like-a-Drum), etc. These can be incredibly inspiring and keep your mind tuned into the recording process.  I sort of use this as my "fix" when I am not able to work actively on a project. Otherwise, what everyone else has said about mixing are perfect suggestions. Maybe set limitations like only using plugins you haven't used. or remove a plugin you are constantly using to force yourself out of a habit. Practice editing dramatically even if the track doesn't call for it so you can get your editing chops up.

author: ehutton21
content: Not gonna lie though I think stock plugins get slept on even when we try to hype them up. The guys who produced “No Problem” for chance the rapper used entirely stock tools, mike dean and a bunch of other mixers I see are routinely skipping pro-q for the stock EQ. Just the other day when i was mixing a demo track i recorded, I made myself use stock plugins for about 80% of it cause I still had a lot of production work to do but it could use some cleaning. Honestly, the mix sounded just as good (if not better) and my production work went over better because latency wasn’t an issue and I didn’t have to worry about committing.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Good point Peter. And this is very different in mastering than in mixing. Mixing is much more collaborative, in mastering the artist/mixer/producer have all done everything they can, and explored every option. Now it’s time to finish. So it’s my job to have a definitive take, and if I’m any good and they’ve chosen me for me aesthetic then it should be right most of the time.

author: ALXCPH
content: Getting in the hours is great for honing your skills. For sure! And there is no wrong way to do it. But getting those 10,000 hours in is a lot more fun if you are enjoying what you are doing, and not hating every second of it. You don’t have to love the music, but if you hate every project you work on, I think burn out will be inevitable. I like the fact that you spun into a challenge and made it fun by using it as a way to learn even more. But let’s say you wanna be a mix engineer and work on hip hop. If you spend 10,000 hours only mixing country because it’s what pays. You’ll probably never end up where you wanted to go

author: peterlabberton
content: And hell, there's some real cross training involved! Don't know how exactly, but maybe those years of working on country records informs your hip-hop mixing, or vice versa. I definitely feel like my work on the projects I'm most passionate about benefits from the years spent working in genres I never actually listen to.

content: So , I don’t really watch tv or anything just music related or science related docs . So (and I know it catches shade ) MWTM is my Netflix bro . author: Joshua Riley
content:
Been doing some searching of the Discord this afternoon but struggling to find much. 

I’d love to hear some wisdom on the generalist vs specialist topic

I’m personally just a mixer. Mostly pop music. A lot of my work is with producers or self produced artists and overseeing the final engineering of a project (mixing the track and then passing off to an ME)
I’m also one of the young ones so a lot of my connections that I make and work are through social media whether it be artists or producers. I don’t want to open a can of worms but I’m just finding so many people that are wearing the generalist hat (specifically from a producer standpoint). Seeing a lot of credits that involve one person Co-writing, producing, mixing and mastering a record or seeing a lot of productions where the mixer is completely bypassed because the prod & mix is done by the same person. Would just love to hear peoples opinions on the topic

author: Josh Bowman
content: Biggest thing for any post audio mix- find out the delivery specs before you mix it (ie broadcast or web only, surround or stereo or both) and setup your mix so your music, dialog, and sfx masters are doing any buss processing and leave your master/mix buss clean aside from final limiter. You wanna make sure the stems add up to the final mix exactly if possible to avoid future shenanigans. Label things very clearly. Otherwise just make it sound good! A lot of ad/agency people like the dialog pretty hot I find.  I’m actually not sure what OMV means. But I’ve been out of the ad mixing game for a few years so maybe I’m blanking. Did it full time briefly tho and delivered a bunch of network stuff so 🤷‍♂️

author: Josh Bowman
content: I still have a toe in- but don’t go looking actively for post gigs. I’d say 85% of my work is music mixing, and the rest is tv/ad stuff when it comes up. but doing it full time as a staff engineer wasnt for me. Lots of “dog and pony shows”  for clients… annoying agency people, plus I was getting fat from all the catering 😂 If I ever pursue it actively again it will be on my own and not working for a studio. I mainly just don’t love working for other people I guess might actually be the take away

author: BatMeckley
content:
There’s a perfect example happening right now. I’m mixing a few live songs for an artist with near a million followers who’s normally produced by one of my all time fav producers.

On my first pass, I didn’t try and ordain what I thought the artist would want (which is where this whole covnversation started) I did the absolute best I could to make it what I thought the absolute best it should be. I didn’t use “I was guessing what THEY wanted” as an excuse, I did the best i could so I could stand by my work. 

But at the end of the day, im not producing or writing it, I’m just mixing it, so I have to serve what they want at the end of the day. So when I got their mix revision notes, which was to raise one of the three backing vocalists up a db, I happily obliged and sent it off.

author: Matt Huber
content:
So, first of all, thanks to the buds here who appreciate what I’ve posted in the past.

Second of all, my thoughts on this:
 
I have a personal rule that I will NOT post anything that feels like EFFORT or out of a motivation to game the algo. If I’m “making content” and notice that I’m doing so out of a place that is less than genuine, I will just delete and move on. 

For me, the “mix tips” thing came out of a sincere place of excitement and passion. I would, as a growing mix engineer, stumble upon something that excited me, and I would find myself wanting to turn around to the people in the room to share…well, there’s almost never anyone in the room with me. So, I channeled that passion and excitement in a genuine way to share with the small community of mixers, mastering engineers and producers that I knew on IG. 

At the beginning of my career on to the middle of my career, that became a very fruitful source of business for me - people who followed me on IG, who enjoyed my posts, and began to view me as someone who MIGHT know a thing or two about mixing. 

As my career has developed and my clientele has growing, that has become less important, but it was absolutely pivotal in helping me build a deep bench of great clients, both indie and signed. 

But…I NEVER did it for that reason. It was always (and continues to be) a genuine result of my passion for what I do.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Brings up an interesting point about latency and drivers...   So what latency do you work at?  

My RME setup can average 64 buffer samples (3ms)  in my primary scoring template of about 30 instances of Kontakt. When I was still using the RME AIO pci card the same template could run at 32 samples 1.5ms latency. Mixing is where it gets wacky.  Some of these plugins will cause massive latency beyond the audio driver and I can't use them while playing notes in with virtual instruments. 

Also...  direct monitoring is always key for acoustic instruments and the experience is near zero, so the original point wouldn't apply there (correct?)

author: Oli J
content:
Typically wouldn’t do click with subdivision - I run my stems from a full bar and my stem printing code includes the bpm in the folder name. And then committed pro tools mix session for the MD. Artists typically have wildly different click tone preferences on stage to studio so better they adjust that when in rehearsals. 
If there’s a session with tempo map then it’s gonna wind up back in pro tools with an MD either way

author: thegreatcarsoni

author: Oli J

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Snares or other sounds, I do have loose process that helps me move keep momentum and focus.

TLDR; It’s a contextual balancing act that takes both the context of the music and the studio environment into account.

Music Context

Phase 1 | Production
- 🔑 Everything will be refined later, so I focus on Momentum > Perfection.
- I feel the core energy of inspiration behind the track and go through sounds with the intention of finding one that captures the essence of the finished vision. Doesn’t matter if it’s excellent at this stage.

Phase 2 | Post-Production Mix
- 🔑 I revisit sounds with the intention to sculpt an emotionally enhancing space for the music to live in (small venue, living room, arena, efc).
- Refine sounds while keeping initial energy in mind, but you can focus more creativity on ‘mixing’ than ‘production’ (at least how my mind perceives them)
- Will likely need to replace a part of the snare stack, but now that more of the tracks vision has bridged the gap between vision to reality it’ll be easier to find a proper pocket and vibe for things. 
- Because that initial sound resonated with me, I’ll try plug-in sculpting before replacing, but I tend to add / replace the sound that emulates the rattle under the snare at this stage + add dimension for the emotional space I’m building.
- 🗒️ Sometimes a diff sample can come with these things off the bat no tweaking needed, its rare though.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
I think power bass can zap SLP readings.  Like...  you could've cranked a sub heavy mix and generated 100db but the upper range wouldn't have nearly enough juice for the room. Just depends on the speaker stacks and mixing style. 

That said...  too loud is a real problem and theres a whole class of Live FOH who push it too hard for too long. Those guys deserve some limits imposed.

Modern DAWs are 32 bit floating point, differences he's hearing may be down to pan law or something that's on maybe without realizing in Logic or Ableton. author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
I’m late to this, but wanted to say my part that I navigate DAWs based on the mindset of the workflow I’m intending to get into.

If I needa hit a new track quick to get a vibe set, FL Studio is amazing for quick production and quickly transforming the studio into a different vibe, but if I need to do a bunch of vocal takes and/or deep mixing juggling chains and transforming that vibe into a captured piece, especially those meant to become a product, I find Pro Tools Ultimate the absolute 🐝s 🦵s for that.

-

They may have patched it and this is old news, but I know FL can’t handle as much CPU and it used to run off of one processor, so my quad processor CPU can’t handle more than 20 tracks in FL, whereas I can I have 200+ tracks on Pro Tools and still run smooth (utilizing freeze and stuff too, which FL doesn’t have) so yeah.

In the end, once a threshold of quality for a tool is passed, it’s a matter taste based preference, and I find my taste varying with projects and my two DAWs capture all the different intentions I find myself having between the two different UIs / Workflows

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: Hey guys, so I wear a lot of different hats in my day to day, as I'm sure a lot of you do. Does anyone else experience a kind of uncertainty/mild anxiety about their work that might derive from the fact that you're not really specialized in a certain area? I feel like I'm not always as excited or confident about getting into a certain task not only because I know i'm not very good at it yet (which i know is all relative, I could still be exactly what someone else needs for something), but also because I know others are out there, sometimes in my personal circle, who are much better? For a little added detail, my fulltime career is as a voice actor, but I love mixing, and sometimes I produce some baby artists, engineer ADR and video game/commercial voiceover. This week i was asked to dialog edit an animated film, I have to comp vocals for someone's song, and there's always a litany of othere stuff, none of which I ever feel prepared to do so the work usually takes longer than I know it should. Maybe the answer is simply to stop trying to be everything to everyone, but honestly I'm terrified to put all my eggs into the voiceover basket even though it's what I've got the most momentum with.
